Suspend drilling operations due to issues with Hex pumps 1, 2 and 3 requiring repair to fluid ends. Hex pump #1 - Leaking liner gasket that is currently being repaired. Failed Module on Hex pump #1 Bay #2 Hex pump #2 - Washed module in #2 Bay. We have one more module in the warehouse to replace this with. We also have had to steal 2 sub rods for the pistons out of this pump to replace one each in pump #1 and #3. We are out of sub rods so this pump will definitely be down until 2 sub rods are received. There are 2 sub rods in the weekly shipment at the dock. Hex pump # 3 is down due to the washed module that was replaced yesterday. New module is installed and going back together with the S pipe. Hope to have it up within the hour. Hex Pump #4 Bay 2 has a valve and seat outside of Suction seat is busted and washed. Unknown at this time, NOV and TFS is still investigating. Unknown at this time. Pick up off bottom and circulate with pumps 4 and 5 until other pumps available. We have submitted a large rig down order of spare parts, CVX has committed to running a special boat for us. TCO ticket 994750 has been opened with NOV and e hawk has been trending the pumps to see is there is a synchronization issue.

Mudpump #1 - Pulsation dampener pressure high pumpman reported pressure on pulsation dampener is high i.e, 3400 psi instead of 1500 psi preset. troubleshoot / investigate. Normal expected wear and tear from operating equipment as designed  Job carried out with RMS# 2230014175563----------, Pumpman Reported Mud pump #1 pulsation dampener pressure shows 3400 psi. Ensured discharge is bleed off and checked the pressure from the filling valve and shows the same 3400 psi.

Mud pump #2 discharge module cap seal is leaking and only one mud pump was available due to pumps 3 and 4 were being worked on. Note that the mud pump uses P-Quip valve cover retention system. The mud pump pumping rate was increased from 1000gpm to 1200gpm, and the pressure increased to 4950psi during the pump rate testing. Not long after the pump rate increased, the module cap seals started to fail. The 1200 ft-lb torque used for making up the P-Quip valve cover initially was not sufficient to hold the pressure increase. Note that during drilling the pump pressure was 3600 psi. Increased the bolt torque value to 1400 ft-lbs. Note that P-Quip gives a working range from 600-1900 ft-lbs depending on the pump pressure. Replaced the cap seal, re-torqued the P-Quip valve cover retention system bolts to 1400 ft-lbs when installing the valve cover back and re-torqued the remaining valve covers on mud pump #2.

Install new bleed off valve mud pump room 1) Scope of works: Supply of Demco Gate Valve ND 3" 7500PSI, Flanged with Flange 2 1/16" 10K, BX-152, 4130, including: - Supply of all material needed to carry out the job; - Welding of Flanges at Valve, with 100% X-Ray, Stress Relief; - MPI Inspection in 100%; - HP Testing 1,5 WP; - Blasting & Painting; - Delivery at Transocean yard Macaé; 2) APPLICABLE STANDARDS: - ASME IX B31.3 Process Piping; 3) TESTING AND COMISSIONING: - Final visual inspections of all new works will be carried Failure caused by wear and tear resulting from normal operation of the equipment unit  Parts Requested from ICS:----------, ** Non Issued Parts Auto Cancelled QTY REQUESTED: 4 QTY ISSUED: 0 DESC: VALVE 3 IN 7500 PSI FLANGED 21/16 IN----------, Parts Requested from ICS:----------, Equipment is out of Service This valve washed out during drilling 17 1/2 hole March 14th 2016. No spare available so had to blank it. The flange has been welded up to allow blank install.---------- , AUTOMATED PRIORITY ADJUSTMENT Job priority changed from High(2) to 1 due to revised job priority methodology.----------, Pedro rejected the order for two valves. Due to the quote was only for one valve. So staying with the attached quote. I resummited for only one valve. Req # 0095018327----------, This job is being closed and a new job with new quote will be opened for the installlation of the valve and flanges once it has been updated. Lawrence Gates Mardonildo / Diogo The flanges and the valve required to complete the repairs to # 3 bleed line are onboard and in the mud pump room storage locker. We would require a coded welder out for the installation of the Flanges in order to complete this task I suggest we pencil this in for the same time we carry out the repairs to The TDS power swivel . Attached quote from the original RMS Job created for the repairs please advise if the original quote is good and you approve to carry out the repairs.----------, Equipment is back in Service This valve washed out during drilling 17 1/2 hole March 14th 2016. No spare available so had to blank it. The flange has been welded up to allow blank install.

Remove pulsation dampner from #3 mud pump Remove pulsation dampner from #3 mud pump and install pulsation dampner from #5 mud pump on #3 mud pump. Several causes are acting simultaneously. If one cause is predominant, this cause should be highlighted.  Rebuilt bladder on #1 pump still waiting on parts.----------, Parts Requested from ICS:----------, Developed procedure for removal and installation of pulsation dampners on 14P220 mud pumps. Removed pulsation dampner from #5 mud pump to be installed on #3 mud pump. Removed pulsation dampner from #3 mud pump and mounted on #5 mud pump. Cleaned sealing sufrace on #3 mud pump pulsation dampner mounting flange.----------, Moved Pulsating dampners from #5 to #3 Mud pump and #1 to #2 mud pump. All bolts have been torqed on all four pumps. #1 and #5 need to have bladders rebuilt.

OOS 2018 Dietswell Punchlist Item No14 OOS 2018 Integrated Punchlist Item 14 Repair or Replace the leaking Lube Oil Pump on No4 Mud Pump Normal expected wear and tear from operating equipment as designed  Parts Requested from ICS:----------, Parts Requested from ICS:----------, When testing the L.O. Pump the Discharge Pressure Gauge was found to be faulty so changed same and tested all O/K.----------, ** Non Issued Parts Auto Cancelled QTY REQUESTED: 2 QTY ISSUED: 0 DESC: PUMP ROTARY GEAR FOOT MOUNT NO.2 WITH R----------, Repairs carried out by Alen Lopes & Joytesh Shah. ' 1. Isolated Mud Pump & verified isolation. 2. Removed L.O Pump coupling guard and pump from skid. 3. Cleaned up all pipework and pump base. 4. Installed new pump and pipework. 5. The 12 hrs recorded under Andrew Christie are for Alen & Joytesh's time as they do not have RMS log in details. 6. Pump can not be function tested as the electrical motor failed the inspection and requires to be changed out. (Electrical Dept aware and plan to change out A.S.A.P).----------, 1. Job has been completed and tested.

During final testing of the previously install boost line drape hose on the termination joint a leak was noticed. Troubleshoot leak and it was determined that the #5 mud pump boost line header valve was leaking. Look at servicing schedule of the valves and potential ways to prevent re-occurrence. Grease and function #5 mud pump boost header valve. Change line-ups and retest.

Inspect pistons and liners on MP#2 Isolate MP#2 and inspect pistons and liners on cyl # 2 and 3, suspected leakage as we found mud in liner wash tank. Replace parts as required. Normal expected wear and tear from operating equipment as designed  Inspected pistons and replaced due to scores found. Repaired liner wash hoses.

Pop off valve went on mud pump #2 while drilling @ 3100psi, unable to reset same. Valve did not see a pressure spike and was tested to 3500psi, Noted that during investigation while stripping down the relief valve it was found that the internal seal shaft had (Sub) cracked and broke off the internal sub. Currently inspecting and testing 1 x spare valves, replace old valves for new if required. Installed refurbished complete body and pop off unit. Increased pulsation damper pressure for m 800psi to 1200psi

Wash out on Pistons in MP #1 cyl #2 and MP #3 cyl #1 and cyl #3. Hours on Pistons - 20hrs. Replaced Pistons. 2,5 hrs down time. Continued drilling. After 6 hrs observed new wash out on MP #3 cyl #1. Replaced Piston. 1 hr down time. Continued drilling. After 2 hrs observed new wash out on MP #3 cyl #1. Replaced Piston. 1 hr down time. All Piston rubbers were worn out/dissolving - Premature wear - Suspect bad batch of pistons (rubber) - To be investigated *). OEM Pistons from NOV batch 0000068568 suspected to be of poor quality. Remaining Pistons from this batch removed from stock. *) To be reviewed with shore support for follow-up. Checked aligment on extantion rod - liner on MP ## cyl #1.OK. Inspected condition on Pistons in all Mud pumps. OK. Replaced Pistons.

MP #1 & MP #2 shut down while drilling ahead. Intermittent fault with MP #1 & #2 BX Titan PRV control panel, causing the pressure readings to spike erratically which caused the mud pumps to shut down. After consulting with NOV and TFS, found that we have spare panel in the warehouse. Configured and installed the panel and got the MP #1 and MP #2 working again. Continued drilling ahead with reduced flow rate with two mud pumps (#3 & #4).

Failed valve cap seal on mud pump 4 bay 3 suction module whilst drilling 16.5" x 20" hole section under MPD conditions. Failed cap seal. Continue to inspect and verify condition at every opportunity. Fluid weep observed from tell tale indication of impending failure of valve cap seal on MP4. TOFs held. MOC process conducted. Controlled change over for mud pump line up. The MPD process means utilizing cementer to pump and allow cement pump to take over booster pump task to allow controlled reduction on drill string flow whilst maintaining back pressure on well. Reducing flow on string whilst XT reamer is in the BHA also triggers re-indexing event on the reamer as string pumps are cycled. Mud pump repaired "Offline"

Trouble getting pressure on MP 3 Leak on booster valve. - To be investigated when operation allows valve to be dismantled. RMS job made to repair valve.Checked that the valve are on maintenance plan ok. Stop and restart pump. vent supercharge. Found leaking valve on MP'3 to booster valve

Work mud pump # 1 suction module ( center) Remove center suction module. Failure caused by wear and tear resulting from normal operation of the equipment unit  Due to continued leaks on module after seat valve and plug changed decision was made to change the module. After module changed bolts torqued the pump was tested and no leaks observed. Pump is running as intended.----------, Parts Requested from ICS:----------, Parts Requested from ICS:

Suction manifold PRV passing on mud pump #3 Suction PRV has reached the end of its serviceable life. There is no adjustment on this PRV and the spring is no longer strong enough to hold the 70 psi as it should. At the time of the event mud pump #4 was isolated for a similar problem. Downtime caused by the fact we had to stop drilling and circulate until mud pump #4 was de-isolated. Ordered 4 new suction PRV's for the mud pumps on RMS job #2270029176944 De-isolated mud pump #4. Mud pump #3 isolated and removed the suction manifold PRV, mechanic function and pressure tested same with no success. Suction PRV was replaced with an already tested spare. Both suction and discharge filters cleaned. Discharge filter observed to be fairly dirty. Opened the suction and discharge modules and inspected the valves and seats, replaced valve and seat on discharge module #2 - this was not effecting the suction PRV.

Blower motor (B) on mud pump #3 tripped two times @ 16:30 and 16:51 hours causing motor (B) to trip. Due to run speed and pressure of the mud pump, the loss of a motor would cause the mud pump to shut down. Electricians believe that a faulty pressure switch on the mud pump #3 blower (B) is causing the issue. Electricians to continue trouble shooting blower motor (B) on mud pump #3 to verify if the pressure switch is the culprit, or if another problem exists. Pressure switch was replaced, no further issues observed. Also, Engineering group is working with NOV to remove the loss of blower pressure as a Shutdown condition as this is historically treated as a Start Inhibit. Mud pump #3 was able to return to operation by simply turning the mud pump off, and then turning back on. On second shut down of the mud pump the lineup was changed to place Mud Pump #3 on the boost line to reduce the workload on the pump.

Change out faulty L.O pump pressure gauge Change out faulty L.O Pump Pressure Gauge Equipment did not perform as intended per designed specification and not due to lack of maintenance  Parts Requested from ICS:----------, Found mud pump no# 3 lube oil leak from pressure gauge same changed with new one.

Mud pump motor B failed on mud pump 4 whilst drilling 17-1/2" hole. Mud pump was shut down and operations resumed with remaining 3 mud pumps. This event was the direct cause of improper lubrication to the mud pump motor. This can also be attributed to not following PM procedures, not following PMSR procedures, and also having inadequate reactivation procedures. Other mud pumps bearings evaluated with temperature gun and thermal imaging to verify no hot spots were present. Crews made aware of lubrication procedures for different motors and all motors greased as per these procedures. Mud pump 4 shut down and drilling operations resumed. TOFS and MOC conducted. Mud pump isolated and swapped out with spare motor stored on the rig.

Rebuild manual bleed off valve Rebuild manual bleed off valve Normal expected wear and tear from operating equipment as designed  Parts received----------, ** Non Issued Parts Auto Cancelled QTY REQUESTED: 2 QTY ISSUED: 0 DESC: disc rupture specified 5172 psi at 72 f QTY REQUESTED: 2 QTY ISSUED: 0 DESC: wrench rupture disk plug for 31/16 in----------, Parts Requested from ICS:

TROUBLESHOOT ABNORMAL TORQUE AND POWER READINGS Breakdown Job Normal expected wear and tear from operating equipment as designed  MUD PUMP RAN FOLLOWING THE REPLACEMENT OF THE PORT SIDE BELT 3A RPM 509 Mact 800 I act 400 V out 347 P out 40 3B RPM 512 Mact Neg 190 I act 395 V out 348 P out Neg 10 MUD PUMP RAN FOLLOWING THE REPLACEMENT OF THE PORT SIDE BELT AND WITH LOAD 3A RPM 393 Mact 3420 I act 512 V out 273 P out 140 3B RPM 394 Mact 2660 I act 475 V out 273 P out 115----------, MEASURED MOTOR CURRENT VALUES AND COMPARED WITH VFD CURRENT READINGS. MP 3A VFD Iact = 392 Motor Phase Measurement 392 Per Phase MP 3B VFD IAct = 396 Motor Phase Readings 396 Per Phase----------, 24/4/18 CNR PUNCHLIST ITEM 304 POWER IMBALANCE BETWEEN A ND B MOTOR We assigned all mud pumps in a controlled manner in order to easily check the Bender feedback. MP1 140k MP3 135K MP4 115K MP5 115K We then ran MP3 up to 80rpm in order to observe the reported difference in torque and power feedback. See link to video which clearly show a large difference in torque and power values basically the values on B motor are always reading negative. I:\Electrical\#3 Mud Pump\Mud Pump 3\20180424_071329.mp4 Note no alarms were activated during the test. Following this we test ran each motor individually and observed the following readings. Motor 3A RPM 206 Mact 400 Nm Iact 380a Vout 140v Pact 10Kw Motor 3B RPM 207 Mact 400 Nm Iact 380a Vout 140v Pact 10Kw Following the discovery of an old email (see attached) which mentions issues with both MP 3 and 5 dating from back in 2011 we ran MP and the following readings were observed. As you can see MP 5 shows similar differences. MP5A. RPM 822.1 Mact 300 Nm Iact 400a Vout 561v Pact 30Kw Motor 5B RPM 820.8 Mact 700 Nm Iact 400a Vout 561v Pact 60Kw For good measure we also checked MP1 and MP4. As you can see MP1 looks fairly balanced however MP4 shows similar differences in Torque and Power. Motor 1A RPM 820 Mact 500 Nm Iact 400a Vout 560v Pact 45Kw Motor 1B RPM 820 Mact 500 Nm Iact 400a Vout 560v Pact 45Kw MP4A. RPM 821 Mact 700 Nm Iact 400a Vout 560v Pact 61Kw Motor 4B RPM 822 Mact 400 Nm Iact 400a Vout 560v Pact 32Kw----------, MUD PUMP 3 RAN WITH LOAD. 3A RPM 810 Mact 3660 I act 515 V out 559 P out 321 3B RPM 820 Mact 2050 I act 450 V out 562 P out 178----------, Folloing the discovery of emails dating back from 2009/20011 which indicated that incorrect belt and pulley allignmnet was the probable cause of the issue it was decided to check mud pump 3. Motor isolated for mechanical checks THE FOLLOWING READINGS WERE TAKEN FOLLOWING THE FIRST MECHANICAL ADJUSTMENT Motor 3A RPM 815 Mact 1510 Nm Iact 416a Vout 558v Pact 128Kw Motor 3B RPM 824 Mact Neg 530 Nm Iact 404a Vout 561v Pact Neg 47Kw----------, FOLLOWING THE FINAL TEST MAINT SUP WAS ABLE TO CLOSE OUT THE ISSUE WITH CLIENT.----------, Checked belt alignment; 3a found slightly off one turn of the adjustment screw made the alignment of motor visually perfect using a wire clamped from one sheave to the other. Belt tension checked at 85 psi. 3b aligned earlier.----------, THE FOLLOWING READINGS WERE TAKEN FOLLOWING THE 2ND MECHANICAL ADJUSTMENT OF MP3. Motor 3A RPM 815 Mact 1500 Nm Iact 420a Vout 558v Pact 130Kw Motor 3B RPM 823 Mact Neg 500 Nm Iact 405a Vout 560v Pact Neg 45Kw----------, THE FOLLOWING READINGS WERE TAKEN FOLLOWING THE 1ST MECHANICAL ADJUSTMENT OF MP4. Motor 4A RPM 815 Mact 1500 Nm Iact 420a Vout 558v Pact 130Kw Motor 4B RPM 823 Mact Neg 500 Nm Iact 405a Vout 560v Pact Neg 45Kw

Mud Pump #3 - adjust belt tension Meassure and adjust belt tension Common cause / mode  Found Stbd side Belt need adjusting. Loosen all electric motor mounted bolts and Adjusted STBD side belt . Checked belt tension with hydraulic tool and all is in tolerance 7/8 movement with 205psi pressure Tightened El.motor bolt to 1850 Ft/Lb . Removed all tools from work site and done housekeeping. Deisolated pump. unit back in service.----------, observed while running .checked for alarms and all okay.----------, Due to belt slip alarm checked belt tension Found Port side Belt slack Adjustment of belt is ongoing Adjusted Port side belt pulled slide motor plate for approx.. 1314 mm Checked belt tension with hydraulic tool and all is in tolerance 7/8 movement with 200 psi pressure Tightened El.motor bolt to 1850 Ft/Lb

While drilling 12 1/4" hole mud pump #2 went down due to swab. Prior to completion of swab change out another swab on mud pump #3 failed thus drilling ops ceased due to not being able to provide sufficient flow. Hours on swabs were 500h and 336h normal wear and tear Reviewed hours on remaining swab and assessed reduction in hour requiring change out Picked up off bottom / continued circulating with mud pump # 1 and changed out failed swabs

Pumping slug with MP 3: Set speed ref to 5 spm, actual 10 spm. Reduced speed ref to 0 spm, actual 10 spm. Engaged e-stop. Switched over VFD to MP 1. Root Cause not Identified - Not able to re-produce fault. (Could be that mud pums with low speed ref, has stopped on piston stroke flag, and the motor has moved back and forth against this flag, which is trigging a prox. - This issue has been tested with same speed ref, and is working every time. (Not able to re-produce fault). Tested, and not able to re-produce this fault. Switched to MP 1 and pumped slug

Having downhole detection issues while running Mud pump #2 and #3 while repairing #1 Hex pump fluid end. Wear on pump parts. Change out high hour parts on Mud Pumps. Change out valves and seats in # 1 Mud Pump

Replace rupture disk on MP#4 Change disk on MP#4 WOM valve. The equipment was operated beyond capacity of the Equipment Technical Specifications.  Parts Requested from ICS:----------, Installed new disk on MP4.

While drilling 12 1/4 hole at depth 2401m, observed fluid discharging from top of Pulsation dampener on #2 mud pump.. Bladder in dampener failed. Loss of pressure. Follow RMS procedures, regular checks while in use. Age of bladder that we replaced was 20 months. Last replaced 23rd March 2018. TOFS. Shut down pumps and isolate #2 mud pump. Circulate clean and POOH to shoe. Start replacement of bladder in pulsation dampener. Replace same.

Troubleshoot and repair MP#1B blower issue Troubleshoot and repair MP#1B blower issue Failure caused by wear and tear resulting from normal operation of the equipment unit  Continued with assembling of blower and filter housing . re Installed Impeller filter housing tested at deck rigged up in place wired up heat shrinked damaged wires of incoming cable Test ran blower unit for an hour Measured and recorded amps and bearing temperature of DE and NDE bearings No abnormal Noise . All good. De isolated closed the paper work. IR Value 25 M ohms 14.5 Amps equal DE /NDE 39°C /35°C start of test DE/NDE 44.5°C /37°C End of test .----------, Dismantled the blower unit observed the abnormal sound from motor replaced both bearings with 6309 C3 from shipyard spares motor is ready and reassembling on going----------, 03042017 Observed there was a strange noise coming from blower housing and planned to repair blower with the available parts . The task been carried as below . 1.Raised PTW and EISO for the task . 2.Arranged lifting gears shackles from deck crew . 3.Disconnected motor at Terminal box and removed the cable gland . Secured the cable in the tray . 4.Disconnected earth cable from the motor body . 5.Disjointed the Blower & motor assembly from main motor . 6.Lifted with movable chain block and brought it down to deck . 7.Opened up filter housing and rotated the impeller by hand and looked for any visible problems . 8.Meggered the motor and measured winding resistance . 151 Mohms and winding resistance are equal .

TOFS taken to deal with multiple HEX Pump fluid end valve/seat/swab failures plus standpipe valve leaking while drilling. Drilling with over 6300psi, Fluid end valve and seats, swabs on all pumps plus #4 Hex Pump #2 standpipe leaking. Valves and swabs within their change-out hrs. Replaced valves/seats/swabs and repair kit on #4 HEX pump #2 standpipe valve.

Observed leak on piston number #1 on MP #2. Also observed noise from piston #2. Worn piston / washout. Evaluate to change piston on a more frequent hrs. Decided to replace both pistons. Isolated MP and changed piston on cylinder 1 & 2 on MP #2

During drilling operations a drilling fluid leak was observed on one of the cylinders. Component wear. Unable to maintain drilling flow rate as one of the mud pumps was getting the drive motor changed out. 2 mud pumps down simultaneously. nan Changed out worn fluid end components - new Liner and piston fitted.
Mud pump #2 boost valve leaking. Wear and cuts on inside components of boost valve. nan Change out inside components of mud pump #2 boost valve.
During drilling operation mud pump #1 #1 piston failed due to a wash wear and tare and high mud temperatures More regular checks isolate mud pump and change out piston for new

OOS 2018 Dietswell Punchlist Item No13 OOS 2018 Integrated Punchlist Item 12 Repair or Replace the leaking Lube Oil Pump on No2 Mud Pump Normal expected wear and tear from operating equipment as designed  Parts Requested from ICS:----------, Repairs carried out by Alen Lopes & Joytesh Shah. ' 1. Isolated Mud Pump & verified isolation. 2. Removed L.O Pump coupling guard and pump from skid. 3. Cleaned up all pipework and pump base. 4. Installed new pump and pipework. 5. Deisolated & function tested L.O Pump. 6. Pump relief valve was set up. 7. Pump run for 15 mins with discharge pressure recorded at 90psi. 8. No leaks observed during this test. 9. The 12 hrs recorded under Andrew Christie are for Alen & Joytesh's time as they do not have RMS log in details.

Order complete blower assembly for the mud pump and replace the degrading ones. Order complete blower assembly for the mud pump and replace the degrading ones. None of the above codes applies. Specify cause as free text.  I have added a min/max of 0/1 for a complete blower assembly as this is a stock item. In light of this I am closing this job out.----------, This job is being made for ordering a complete blower motor assembly for the degrading ones.Recently we had a degrading mud pump blower and this is being fixed on job number 165253 by assembling the motor and impellor available as we dont complete assembly which is properly balanced.These units need a good balancing for long life without abnormal vibrations.Balancing cannot be achieved onboard. Since we dont have complete mud pump blower assembly.We will need to order this one to replace a degrading one.Then we might get a chance to rotate the other blower assembly locally and get it refurbished.This tag for mud pump is used only ordering the new assembly.

Electronic relief valve on mud pump no 3 was activated during a connection. There was no indication that to high pressure was the cause. Not able to reset the relief valve. Damage pressure transmiter caused the BX Titan valve to open. When this condition happens the BX Titan valve is programmed to go into fail safe mode and fail safe is open valve; fail safe open. Failed Pressure transmitter is send onshore to NOV/Vendor for analyses. MSN nr 1032000054 and NOV ticket 808994. Review maintenance history in RMS for POP OFF on mud pump 1-2-3 from installation in 2016 and until now and see if the maintenance is correct or if modification is needed. Lesson Learned AAR is to be informed to Drill Crew and Technical Crew so if this fault happened again we are reducing the off line time for this equipment Attempting to reset pop off several times. The alarms "Discharge pressure signal fault" and "Titan BX valve tripped" could be read on the contoller box. Trouble shooting in both the BX Controller box/cabinet and the pressure transmitter to try to pin point the problem. At the same time the mechanich was looking into solutions to use the air from the manifold box controlling the pop off nr 2, to keep the pop off open with that signal. Electrician was able to measeure the signal from the pressure transmitter and found out this was not working. Replaced pressure transmiter on MP #3 and the pop off valve closed.

While drilling 17 1/2 hole on Z4, driller observed pressure drop on stand pipe manifold. Derrickman reported a wash on #2 fluid end piston. Drilling with 4200 l/m and 280 bar. Failure of piston rubber. Total hours on piston 294. Regular checks on mud pumps while drilling. Shut down pump, isolate pump. TOFS. Change piston.

Replace MP3 pulsation dampener diaphram Replace MP3 pulsation dampener diaphram Topp off nitrogen to 2000psi Several causes are acting simultaneously. If one cause is predominant, this cause should be highlighted.  Parts Requested from ICS:----------, Mud Pump 3: Remove the Air operated hoist on the trolley and install a manual hoist for the task. Gather all tools and equipment as needed. Create a new RRP and WRA for replacing the bladder. Isolated the mud pump and the fluid end valves. Removed the fill valve and gauge. Removed the top cover and found that the hex bolt that secures the stabilizer to the diaphragm had back out. The stabilizer was found to be split and in poor condition. Rigged up lifting eye and removed the diaphragm. Clean the flange and cavity and fit the new diaphragm. Reinstall the cover fill valve and gauges. Rig up and fill with 2000psi nitrogen pre charge.

Assist Replace MP 1A Drive Motor Assist Replace MP 1A Drive Motor due to noisy on NDE bearing. Equipment did not perform as intended per designed specification and not due to lack of maintenance  Deisolate for function testing. Completed function test. Run the pump from 10 SPM to 60 SPM. Found running in good condition. Isolate again. Weld the block stopper on the motor. Weld the cable bracket.----------, Assisted Electrical Team with removal Terminal Junction Box. Removed the blower.----------, 17 Mar 2018 with drill crew and S/TP removed the old motor. Verified new motor had same footing and same pulley. Brought down new motor to mud pump room. 18 Mar 2018 drill crew lift the motor to the skid plate. Installed the top cover. 19 Mar 2018: : Found the skid plate threaded hole not align with the new motor holes. Only two holes were aligned. Observed that the mounting holes of old motor had been enlarged on two of them. Discussed with Maintenance Supervisor for enlarging the new motor mounting holes. Cut flame the holes and use pencil grinder to clean the holes. Tighten the motor to the skid plate and skid plate to mud pump base.----------, Loosen the skid plate of motor and jack the plate to loosen the belt (21/4 socket for skid plate 23/8 socket for adjuster bolt). Removed drive belt. Attempted to remove pulley to gain more space with no success. Rig up for lifting the motor weight 3.4 ton. Loosen the bolts which securing the motor to the skid plate----------, Raised isolation for the job. Prepared tools. Rig up lifting gear ans inertia reel. Removed the belt drive cover. Removed ducting of MP1A Blower.----------, Electrical Department successfull with the ID Run. Loosen skid plate mounting bolts and skid out the motor for installing belt drive.----------, Installed covers ducting and prox switch for manual cranking.----------, Installed belt drive. Aligned and tightened the motor. Fabricated rubber gasket for blower and ducting mounting. Lift and installed the blower in place.

When starting up Mud pumps there were belt slippage on mud pump. Belts between motor and pump slipped. The load on electrical motorr are not even or to big for the belt causing it to slip. Letting out smoke in the pumproom. Mud pumps stoped for time out and check We have been in contact with ABB and await a feedback on freqensy drive software update. Worn belts on MP 2 and 3 are beeing canged out Pump and area checked for heat. Drives for pump 2 &3 resat and mut pums started in steps. With wachman in pumproom

During drilling operations the pump hand observed mud coming from the liner coffin on mud pump 3. Upon investigation it was found that all 6 mounting studs for the liner retention system had parted, allowing the swab and liner system to pull away from the wear plate on the fluid end. Old style liner gasket from NOV was used in this particular pump. Reference HQS-OPS-TIB-016 to ensure the correct type of liner gasket is being used and in the warehouse. Deactivated the RIN for the old style gaskets (RIN 772439) to ensure that the new style Polyurethane gaskets are ordered as per HQS-OPS-TIB-016 . Removed studs and installed new with new nuts. Lubricated Bolt with TS70 moly and torqued as per NOV manual to 1100 ft. lbs at increment's of 25%, 50%, 75% then 100% of full torque rating.

During Drilling Operations with three Mud Pumps the Drilling Department reported erratic indications with flow rates and pressures etc. Maintenance Department called and initial diagnosis was an imbalance with regards Load Sharing of the Mud Pumps. However, after further testing this proved to be false. Further investigation revealed an issue with Mud Pump #3 DC Drive Motor A. Drilling Department informed and Mud Pump #3 taken out of operation and isolated for further investigation. Drilling Operations continued with two Mud Pumps at reduced flow rates etc. Mud Pump #3 DC Drive Motor A - Flashover of the Commutator due to excessively worn Motor Brushes. SPM-C_MTR_ALL-DC-HOR-MOUNT-500+_90-ELECTRICAL Calendar based PM Task last completed on Mud Pump #3 Drive Motor A on 19 Sep 2018. RMS Job Task 17-1227416 refers. Approximate Mud Pump #3 Run Hours at this time - 34267Hrs. Mud Pump #3 Run Hours on 22 Dec 2018 recorded as 35176Hrs. Above Calendar based PM Task next scheduled 5 Jan 2019. In light of the above issue, RMS C/R 1700001002553 submitted to increase the frequency of this Calendar based PM Task to every 60 Days or alternatively change the PM Task to Usage Based every 750Hrs Mud Pump Run Time. As indicated above, after initial fault investigation, Drilling Operations recommenced with two Mud Pumps, Mud Pump #1 & Mud Pump #2, at a reduced flow rate. Mud Pump # 3 isolated, Drive Motor A worn Motor Brushes removed, Drive Motor cleaned internally, Commutator inspected, dressed as required, confirmed serviceable and replacement Motor Brushes installed. Drive Motor electrical readings taken and confirmed the Drive Motor as serviceable. Drive Motor B Motor Brushes checked and confirmed serviceable. Mud Pump #3 de-isolated and tested with assistance from the Drilling Department. Mud Pump confirmed fully serviceable and returned to normal Operations. Further checks on Mud Pumps #1 & #2 Drive Motors confirmed Motor Brushes on these Motors serviceable.

Check Mud Pump 3A Motor Winding RTD's Check Mud Pump 3A Motor Winding RTD's Normal expected wear and tear from operating equipment as designed  This job can be closing now as we don't get an alarms since all rtd's connections was checked.----------, This job created to follow up on issue with Mud Pump 3A motor high temperature alarms happened during operation on 16042019. Checked Mud Pump 3A Motor winding thermistors. Disconnected and checked all RTD's resistance. RTD #1: 113.5 ohms RTD #2: 113.6 ohms RTD #3: 113.1 ohms Spare RTD's reading are 113.0 113.8 ohms. Reconnected all wiring and RTD's. Checked all terminal connections for tightness. Equipment back in serive.

Drilling suspended while troubleshooting low charge pressure on hex pumps. While drilling 16-1/2" OH at 1050gpm with 14.1ppg SBM (& boosting at 350gpm = 1400gpm total) we encountered the suction charge pressure on the hex pumps slowly reducing from ~65psi down to ~15psi and triggering the pump to shut down once the charge pressure dropped below the threshold of 20-15 psi (as per design of the hex pumps). Within the last week, we had displaced the riser from 12.4ppg to SW (tropical storm), went back to mud and have weighted up to 14.1ppg. We had cleaned all the suction strainers on 10-21-19 (minimum in them) after displacing back to mud and seeing similar trends. We will continue to monitor charge pressure and take appropriate actions to minimize downtime, by precautionarily checking suction strainers when operations allow. We cleaned suction strainers (finding minimum material in same), added mud to active system to increase hydrostatic pressure on suction lines, swapped from port side active pits (normal line up) to starboard side active pits, checked for unusual barite fill in pump suction lines, checked milliamps on suction pressure transducers, tried multiple pump line ups / configurations including all pumps running at moderate speed to minimum pumps running at high speed.

No.1 mud pump PRV, Order replacement TITAN P.R.V. While we do have a safety clamp for this particular valve it could not be placed on this no. 3 mud pump because of structural clearance between the valve and high pressure pipe work. We have placed the new valve at this location will rebuild or reseal the valve that was removed and place it on a different pump and use the safety clamp.----------, Valve has been tested on the Mud Side by drilling dept. No leaks found. Valve in full service now.----------, Equipment is back in Service Tagged as OOS. This valve did not fail. Awaiting drilling dept to test the mud side of the BX Titan before signing off the job as completed.----------, Equipment is out of Service Tagged as OOS. This valve did not fail. Pumps started jacking off, picked up to neutral weight. Carried out troubleshooting one pump at a time to establish cause. Problem identified with MP1. Shut in MP1 at standpipe and bled off. Lined up MP2 and MP3 and staged up parameters to milling rate. Once operations allowed Pump was opened up and a small section of wood was found across #2 suction Valve. Pumps will continue to be fluid checked and strainers cleaned out, regularly. Number one mud pump was shut in and operations continued with Mud pump #2 and Mud pump #3.

While drilling out cement plug mud pump #4 cylinder #2 failed. This event appears to have been caused by defective swabs. After further investigation, 11 of the the remaining 16 swabs on the warehouse shelf were inspected and found that the brand new swabs had cracks and clear separation. (See attached) Work together with maintenance supervisor to remove the defective swabs from circulation to replace with quality equipment. Damaged swab has been removed and replaced. Normal operations have resumed.

While circulating at well section TD, mud pump 3 went into alarm for current imbalance. Upon further investigation it was found that the drive pulley was no longer attached to the drive motor. Event was caused by drive pulley no longer being attached to drive motor. Continue to monitor other mud pumps as normal while awaiting further instructions from NOV. Mud pump 3 shut in and drilling operations resumed. TOFs and MOC conducted. Mud pump isolated. Motor has been removed and will be replaced with spare unit currently in transit ETA 21st June.

Whilst drilling ahead 12 1/4" Hole, Swab on Mud Pump #1 Centre Module started to leak, Driller picked string off bottom & drilling was suspended. Note: Unable to achieve sufficient flow rate as repairs were being carried out to Mud Pump #3 at the time, continue to circulate at reduced rate with Mud Pump #1 only. Leaking Mud Pump swab due to expected wear & tear. Leaking Mud Pump swab due to expected wear & tear. Blockage in liner cooling system was caused by OBM leaking into the cooling water tank when the swab leaked & prior to the mud pump being shut down. Mud pump was electrically & mechanically isolated, Swab was replaced. After swab replacement the Liner cooling system was found to be blocked & had to be cleared & flushed adding additional time pump was off-line.

Mud pump 1 - 6" piston failed. Premature failure of piston after just 101 hours. We are currently appraising performance of both white lightening and Patriot piston for our HPHT drilling. Failing to perform controlled switch over from booster pump to online string line up would involve opening WOM gate valves under differential pressure. Downtime event is to capture stop drilling event. Held TOFs when mud observed passing 6" piston in mud pump bay 1. Controlled change over for mud pump line up. The MPD process means utilizing cementer to pump and allow cement pump to take over booster pump task to allow controlled reduction on drill string flow whilst maintaining back pressure on well. Reducing flow on string whilst XT reamer is in the BHA also triggers re-indexing event on the reamer as string pumps are cycled.

Piston blew on #1 mud pump and #4 mud pump while drilling 12 1/4" hole section. The piston failure on #1 mud pump, #3 piston. It was taken off line and mud pump #4 was put online, only to have the same failure on #4 mud pump. Now 2 pumps are down due to failure of pistons. Mud pumps( #1 and #4) went down, leaving only #3 mud pump, which can not maintain drilling parameters. The #2 has been down graded due to pulsation dampener and can only be used on the boost to keep it low pressure. Replace #2 Mud Pump Dampener so the pump can be used on the main hole and not just the boost. Discuss with the client about a possible max hour that can be run. Then change piston considering hours only. NOT the wear. Driller continued to circulate with the bit off bottom, while #1 mud pump was isolated and repaired. Mud pump #1 was de-isolated and put back on line. #4 mud pump was isolated and fixed off line after the rig was off down time.
